title: Welcome to the BaiX Lab
text:
Welcome to the BaiX Lab

Our research studies the origin and evolution of mental representations of human groups. In particular, we take a dynamic perspective by asking two essentially interlinked questions: First, how do individual minds adaptively but selectively construct the social world? Second, how does the constructed social world mold individual minds?

Course Title: Topics in Social Psychology
Course Code: PSY 302
Credits: 3
Term: Spring 2024
Prerequisites: Introduction to Psychology (PSY 101) or equivalent





Instructor: Dr. Xuechunzi Bai

Email: baix@uchicago.edu
Office Hours: Tuesdays, 2:00 - 4:00 PM, Kelly Hall 409

Teaching Assistant (TA): Yuhao Zhu

Email: mikezhu@uchicago.edu
Office Hours: Thursdays, 11:00 AM - 1:00 PM, Kelly Hall 405





This course explores advanced topics in social psychology, focusing on how individuals think, influence, and relate to one another. Topics include group dynamics, persuasion, social cognition, attitude change, and the psychological foundations of social interaction.
Students will critically examine contemporary research and apply theories to real-world scenarios, exploring the intersections of psychology and social behavior. By the end of the course, students will develop a deeper understanding of human social behavior and the ways in which psychological principles manifest in everyday life.



By the end of this course, students will be able to: 1. Analyze and interpret key theories of social psychology. 2. Evaluate research findings in the context of social behavior. 3. Apply social psychological concepts to real-world situations and case studies. 4. Understand the influence of group dynamics, social cognition, and cultural factors on behavior.




Textbook: Social Psychology (10th Edition) by Elliot Aronson, Timothy D. Wilson, and Robin M. Akert.
Supplementary Readings:

Social Psychology and Human Nature by Roy F. Baumeister and Brad J. Bushman.

title: Globally Inaccurate Stereotypes Can Result From Locally Adaptive Exploration
text: Stereotypes of social groups have a canonical multidimensional structure, reflecting the extent to which groups are considered competent and trustworthy. Traditional explanations for stereotypes – group motives, cognitive biases, minority/majority environments, or real-group differences – do not specify a broadly applicable mechanism that explains why stereotypes vary along multiple dimensions. We show that multidimensional stratification and the associated stereotypes can result from a simple mechanism: When individuals make self-interested decisions based on past experiences in an environment where exploring new options carries an implicit cost, they are more likely to separate groups. We formalize this theory with the contextual multi-armed bandit problem, use the model to generate testable predictions, and evaluate those predictions against human behavior. Our results show that even well-intentioned and attentive individuals living in diverse environments can inadvertently impede diversity and form incorrect beliefs. A further theoretically motivated experiment shows intervening on the cost of exploration can mitigate stereotypes.
